A French twist on the couple-on-the-run and
road movie genres, American Translation has the handsome wanderer Chris, a young man as unruly as his hair, meeting rich Aurore in a hotel. They share a passionate, ravenous kiss in the bathroom, and soon head out for sex and adventure in his Peugeot van. Their romance is immediate and intense, they quickly hold a wedding ceremony and tattoo a Ã¢â‚¬Å“ringÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ on her finger, because Ã¢â‚¬Å“something deepÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ connects them. The passion between Chris and Aurore is palpable, not only as evidenced in their naked couplings, but also as reflected by cinematographers Barr and Chris Keohane, who film them with a handheld camera that adds an effective layer of intimacy. Barr and Keohane capture ChrisÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ seductive appeal, and AuroreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s unwavering devotion, most notably in a showstopping and extremely erotic/explicit striptease that is sure to arouse a response from viewers. The coupleÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s amorous bliss, however, is soon disrupted when the dark side of ChrisÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ personality suddenly emerges. He makes it painfully clear to Aurore that he doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t like her talking to other guys. And, he soon reveals, he likes picking up, kissing, and Ã¢â‚¬Å“cuddlingÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ young male prostitutes, whom he also kills. Aurore sometimes help dispose of the body. The film is an exploration of the nature of good and evil, free will, and the death of innocence. Arnold and BarrÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s complex investigation of character resists ascribing any one, real/true meaning to ChrisÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ or AuroreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s actions.
